articles.headline: Crucial Spy in Cuba Paid a Heavy Cold War Price
articles.snippet: Rolando Sarraff Trujillo, who was released Wednesday from a Cuban prison where he had been held since 1995, provided information on codes used by Cuban spies.
articles.abstract: Rolando Sarraff Trujillo, who was released Wednesday from a Cuban prison where he had been held since 1995, provided information on codes used by Cuban spies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He was, in many ways, a perfect spy — a man so important to Cuba’s intelligence apparatus that the information he gave to the Central Intelligence Agency paid dividends long after Cuban authorities arrested him and threw him in prison for nearly two decades.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Michael S. Schmidt and Frances Robles

articles.headline: U.S. Companies Clamor to Do Business in New Cuban Market
articles.snippet: American companies were quick to start plans to bring products and services to a market they have not been in for the better part of 50 years — if ever.
articles.abstract: American companies were quick to start plans to bring products and services to a market they have not been in for the better part of 50 years — if ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: PepsiCo wants in. So do Caterpillar and Marriott International.

articles.headline: When Regulators Are Blind to Rules
articles.snippet: In the United States, a series of crises sent out warning signals that were not heeded.
articles.abstract: In the United States, a series of crises sent out warning signals that were not heeded.
articles.lead_paragraph: What happens when you turn over regulatory responsibilities to people who think there is really no need for regulation?

articles.headline: London Tenants Win Battle Against American Private Equity Firm
articles.snippet: The private equity firm Westbrook Partners has thrown in the towel and says it will sell the New Era Estate, a London housing block whose tenants protested its plans to raise rents.
articles.abstract: The private equity firm Westbrook Partners has thrown in the towel and says it will sell the New Era Estate, a London housing block whose tenants protested its plans to raise rents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a cold, gray morning last month, protesters, including the comedian and activist Russell Brand, gathered in front of the stylish London offices of the American private equity firm Westbrook Partners, brandishing signs that read “Westcrooks” and “Social housing not social cleansing.”

articles.headline: Sony Hacking Fallout Includes Unraveling of Relationships in Hollywood
articles.snippet: The attack has disrupted the web of executive, business and talent relationships that stitches together Sony’s core moviemaking operation.
articles.abstract: The attack has disrupted the web of executive, business and talent relationships that stitches together Sony’s core moviemaking operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Washington considers a response to an online attack on Sony Pictures, Hollywood is trying to repair relationships that were shattered by the assault.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Focusing on Future, Cuba Leaves Fidel Castro to History
articles.snippet: A venerable figure to generations of Cubans is fading from daily conversation as his more pragmatic brother, Raúl, reshapes the nation.
articles.abstract: A venerable figure to generations of Cubans is fading from daily conversation as his more pragmatic brother, Raúl, reshapes the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The college students of a surprised Cuba sang karaoke on Thursday afternoon beside a dark green tank memorializing the Cuban revolution. They played dominoes in the shade of the University of Havana law school, where Fidel Castro found his footing as a leader with a pistol at his side.

articles.headline: Lawyers Create Big Paydays by Coaxing Attorneys General to Sue
articles.snippet: A flourishing industry pairs plaintiffs’ lawyers with attorneys general to sue companies, setting off a furious competition among trial lawyers and lobbyists to influence these officials.
articles.abstract: A flourishing industry pairs plaintiffs’ lawyers with attorneys general to sue companies, setting off a furious competition among trial lawyers and lobbyists to influence these officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When they met at the J. W. Marriott Hotel two blocks from the White House, Linda Singer, a former attorney general turned plaintiffs’ lawyer, approached Attorney General Gary King of New Mexico with an unusual proposition.

articles.headline: Cuba Thaw Lets Rest of Latin America Warm to Washington
articles.snippet: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
articles.abstract: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Obama has been lambasted for spying in Brazil, accused of being a warmonger by Bolivia, dismissed as a “lost opportunity” by Argentina, and taunted in Nicaragua by calls for Latin America to draw up its own list of state sponsors of terrorism — with the United States in the No. 1 spot.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and William Neuman

articles.headline: Under Xi, China’s Wave of ‘Weird Architecture’ May Have Peaked
articles.snippet: Ever since President Xi Jinping issued his admonishment against the rise of outlandish and exorbitant buildings across China, government officials, planners and architects have been scrambling to figure out what it means for them.
articles.abstract: Ever since President Xi Jinping issued his admonishment against the rise of outlandish and exorbitant buildings across China, government officials, planners and architects have been scrambling to figure out what it means for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the newest dreamscape in a country clotted with them. When it opens in two years on Beijing’s east side, Chaoyang Park Plaza, a ring of glass towers molded like mountains in a classic Chinese landscape painting and designed by the renowned architect Ma Yansong, will feature apartments, offices and shops.

articles.headline: U.S. Declares Bank and Auto Bailouts Over, and Profitable
articles.snippet: A final sale of stock from what was once General Motors’ finance arm closed a turbulent chapter of the financial crisis, the Obama administration said.
articles.abstract: A final sale of stock from what was once General Motors’ finance arm closed a turbulent chapter of the financial crisis, the Obama administration said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six years after President George W. Bush began the auto bailout, the Obama administration on Friday declared a profitable end to the sweeping federal interventions in Wall Street and Detroit, saying a final sale of stock from General Motors’ former finance arm had closed a turbulent chapter of the financial crisis.
